lines.text: You a real cowboy?
Well that depends on what you think a real cowboy is?
Know how to do 2-step?
You bet.
Wanna prove it?
Now, you gotta learn something - there are just certain things a girl cain't do.
Name one.
I can name serval, pissin' on the side of a wall, gettn laid while your pants are still on...
Why would you want to?
[Bud is upset that Sissy left before he got the rodeo prize]
You did it for her; didn't you?
What?
Practicing, winning, all that, didn't you?
What are you talkin' about?
Because you sure didn't do it for me.
Pam, this ain't no time to start this with me, what are you talking about?

Look, I'm a shit, but I'm not that big a shit. I have to tell you something, remember when you came home from ridding on the bull that first time and the trailer was all clean and flowers around; I didn't do that, Sissy did it, she was there. She left you a note asking you to phone her. I tore it up, cause I was sorta jealous. I wanted to keep my cowboy. You don't love me Bud, and I don't really love you, not like that. So you shouldn't let her get away. But I tell you what, if you ever wanna make her jealous you know where I am.
I gotta go.
My legs are sweatin', momma.
Damn Bud, Ya'll live like pigs!

[to Wes]
HEY TATTOO! You see this here? That there's a weddin' ring. That means we're married! She's MINE, okay?
You know Bud; sometimes even a cowboy's gotta swallow his pride to hold on to somebody he loves.
What do you mean?

Hell I know, I pretty near lost Corrine and the kids a couple of times just 'cause of pride. You know you think that ol' pride's gonna choke you going down but I tell you what ain't a night goes by I don't thank the boss up there for giving me a big enough throat. 'Cause without Corrine and them kids hell I'd just be another pile of dog shit in the canteloupe patch just drawing flys.
I guess so.
Think about it Bud, pride's one of those seven deadlies you know what I mean?
I got a thumb, I got a middle finger!
All cowboys ain't dumb. Some of 'em got smarts real good, like me.

[Bud is interviewing for a job at the oil refinery where Uncle Bob works. His application is being reviewed]
Bud Davis, huh?

[nervous]
My, my full name is Buford Uon Davis, but nobody calls me Buford 'cept my Grandmother, and she's half Indian. My initials are B.U.D., it spells Bud.

[mildly annoyed]
I can spell, boy.
[looks at application more closely]
What pipeline? There ain't no pipeline in Spur!
Yes there is. It came in last Spring. I was workin' on insulatin' it. Then Uncle Bob said you was hiring so I come down here.
Most of our insulatin' work we contract out. But I can start you out as a general helper, a laborer, a gopher. You know what a gopher is, boy?
Well, I suppose it means you go for things.
[pause]
Or it could mean you're an animal...
Yeah, well around here they're on the same level. Start you off right at the bottom, work up.
[Looks at Bud intensely]
But I'm gonna tell you one thing. You're gettin' this job because of your Uncle Bob. He's been here a long time and he's a damn good man.
[pause]
And I'm gonna tell you one thing more. You're gonna have to lose that beard. It's regulations, any kind of a fresh-air mask...
I brought ya some coffee.
Get me a beer.
Bud, if they smell beer on your breath at work -
JUST GET ME A BEER!
Yessir.
What does your daddy do?
Daddy does oil - and all that that implies.
Uh-oh, get out the Alka-Seltzer.
What happened to your face?
Got hit.
Uncle Bob wanted you to be happy. Are you happy?
Yep, yes I am. You?
Yep, I finally got what I wanted. I got a real cowboy.
And I got what I wanted. I finally got myself a real lady.
Bud, the family car's waiting.
The family car's waiting.
